messageBody:
You are very right and you have found a very cool case. It occurs
as follows: As you know, different English language accents will
phonetically write the same word differently. Thus Quickscript from
different places will differ slightly. No surprises here.
But the issue you have found is that the names and examples of
letters and ligatures are themselves pronounced differently by
different English speakers. Thus "eight" (name of a letter in QM) and
"pair" (example used for a ligature in QM) have the same pronunciation
in upper-class-British English but differ in 21st century American
English. The author of the manual spoke
commonwealth-British-like-English hence his examples would be correct
for him and the educated English of the commonwealth. But not all of
them work in 21st century America. Thus the US speaker should probably
not use "pair" or "air" for that ligature because it does not have the
right sound in our dialect (see below)
Generally some of the examples and names of the letters and
ligatures which are clear to one speaker could be ambiguous to
another. This is one reason the names of letters must be chosen with
immense care such that they are pronounced the same in all accents
(which is no small task). I imagine this is why the QM gave letters
"as in" rather than official names and why they are referred to by
number frequently (though inconsistently)

For some real fun, run the Carnegie-Mellon dictionary (which is
American accent English) over the examples in the QM and you'll see it
will sometimes show different spelling than in manual (which was
written with a commonwealth accent).

Another interesting activity is to look up the pronunciation of a
suspicious word in Merriam-Webster (US) and the same word in Oxford
Unabridged (UK)

Anyway this is not the fault of Quickscript or Kingley Read, it is a
fundamental challenge to any phonetic rendering of English and a topic
much discussed even in Academia. It boils down to this paradox: if
there is an official phonetic spelling of a word then there must be an
official pronunciation. We all want an official spelling but no one
wants an official pronunciation if it is not our own (tomato, tomahto,
potato, patahto)

pronunciation of "eight" and "pair" differ according to
Carnegie-Mellon University (US) which shows them (in a nice ascii form) as
EIGHT= EY T
PAIR= P EH R


--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@...> wrote:
>
> I notice that there seems to be some inconsistency on how to spell the
> words Air and Ear. Or it least it seems inconsistent to me. Here is
a chart:
>
> word IPA Literal QS Ligatures
>
> air ÉÉr Ed Ado Roar Air
>
> bear bÉÉr Bob Ed Ado Roar Bob Air
>
> beer bÉªÉr Bob Eat Ado Roar Bob Ear
>
> ear ÉªÉr Eat Ado Roar Ear
>
>
> The problem I see is that the ligatures don't match the literal QS.
> "Air" consists of 3 sounds, and none of them involve Eight, one of the
> pairs in the ligature Air.
>
> Likewise, "Ear" also contains 3 sounds, none of them containing the
> sound "Ed," one of the pairs in the ligature Ear.
>
> Paul
>
